title: The Silurian Candidate
author: Matthew J Elliott
filename: 229 - The Silurian Candidate - Matthew J Elliott_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1: INT. THE TARDIS — CORRIDOR
FX: ACE AND MEL WALK TOGETHER.
What do you mean, “change of plans”, Ace? I thought we were going to Maruthea.
Not since the Professor got that look in his eyes and said, “Actually, Ace, it’s just occurred to me, I’ve got some unfinished business to attend to.” Then he starts pushing buttons on the console.
So?
So, Mel, it seemed like when you left the first time, and I came on board, he suddenly had plenty of unfinished business to attend to.
If you’d lived nine hundred years, you’d probably leave a few loose ends dangling here and there.
Yeah, but your loose ends probably include forgetting to bring the washing in before you went off in the TARDIS.
I never forget anything. Unfortunately.
His loose ends are all about half-finished battles with old enemies: Daleks, Cybermen, Fenric.
What’s a Fenric?
You need to be on your guard when he starts behaving like this. Things could get dangerous.
That’s always true when you’re around the Doctor. Danger’s his middle name. Or possibly his first or last name. I can’t believe I’ve never asked him about that, actually.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 3
Whatever you ask him now, you won’t get an answer. That’s not who the Doctor is now. He’s a lot more secretive. Maybe he always was, and you just didn’t notice because, well...
Because what?
Because he was being secretive.
There was a time in Pompeii. But he was only keeping things from me because-
(INTERRUPTING) He didn’t want you to get hurt. But you did get hurt, didn’t you?
Everybody got hurt; it was Pompeii.
Fine, ask him for yourself. See how straight he is with you.
Maybe I should.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 4
SCENE 2: INT. GORRISTER’S JET — FLIGHT DECK
FX: JET IN FLIGHT. GORRISTER TINKERS WITH ROBOTIC INNARDS.
DEVICE GIVES A SMALL ZAP.
Let’s see if that does the trick.
FX: SHOWER OF SPARKS.
Dammit!
FX: DOOR SLIDES OPEN AND RUTH ENTERS.
Shouldn’t you be at the controls, Gorrister?
Not until we’re over Eastern Bloc airspace and I have to dodge the tracking systems. In the meantime, I’m trying to get the Karlas to function properly.
Don’t tell me you don’t approve of female-gendered robot soldiers.
I don’t approve of anything we’re doing on this mission, Professor.
That’s the difference between you and me. I don’t see this as a mission. It’s just something I have to do, so I’m doing it.
Sounds like a mission to me. One that’d have Chairman Falco tearing his wig off if he knew about it.
But he won’t know about it, will he? That’s why you’re here, as my expert on stealth. The Chairman’1l know what he needs to, when I’m ready to tell him.
Beats me why you won’t trust him.
Oh, don’t tell me; you voted for him.
I like him. He says what’s on his mind.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 5
We can all do that. Your moustache makes you look like my old P.E. Teacher, and she was nothing to write home about. See how easy that was?
It’s going to be a long flight to Motuo if all you’re planning on doing is insulting me.
Can’t the big macho man take it?
You called me, Professor Drexler, because I am a big macho man.
I called you because you owe me a massive debt.
One that could get me shot by the Western Bloc for treason. Or by the Eastern Bloc for spying.
Seems to me, the petulant Frank Gorrister is nearly as unattractive as the tough Frank Gorrister.
Have you ever thought that maybe you just don’t like men?
I don’t like two particular types of men, the sensitive and the senseless.
That doesn’t leave a lot of wiggle room in between.
Then perhaps mankind should take a long, hard look at itself.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 6
SCENE 3: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: THE DOCTOR WORKS AT THE CONSOLE. MEL ENTERS.

(PERFORMING A “DANGEROUS DAN McGREW”-STYLE RECITATION AS HE WORKS) “When through the bar doors burst Abslom Daak, a snarl upon his face; And said to the landlord I’m here to kill, every Dalek in the place...”
Doctor...
Yes, Mel?
Ace says we've changed course.
Does she?
Well?
Well, what?
Have we changed course?
Yes.
Where are we going?
Somewhere else. That’s where you usually go when you change course.
And where is somewhere else?
Home.
Home? We’re going to Gallifrey?
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 7
Not my home, Mel. A few more oceans are going to have to flow under a few more bridges before I’1l be welcome back there.
So my home, then. Earth.
That is your home, isn’t it? Unless I’ve been misinformed.
When?
When we first met, I suppose.
No, I mean what year are we heading for?
About a century after your time. Many things have changed, many others have remained the same.
Funny how that happens. So is there a reason for the diversion?
Does there have to be?
No, it’s just that- Well, I’m dressed for a party. I’d like to know if I’ve got to change.
I often think that would be nice, too. Though in my case, the changes are usually more than just fashion-related.
So are we going to a party or not?
Not a party, no. There’s just something I have to take care of.
Should I be concerned?
I don’t think so, Mel. It shouldn’t take more than an hour. But the effects might last until the end of the world.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 8
SCENE 4: INT. GORRISTER’S JET — FLIGHT DECK
FX: GORRISTER IS TINKERING WITH KARLA AGAIN.
Anything I can do to help? Mop your brow? Offer words of positive reinforcement?
No need. Nearly got- Ha!
FX: A CLICK, AS KARLA ONE ACTIVATES.
SLOW AT FIRST, THEN SPEEDING UP TO NORMAL SPEECH RATE
Congratulations on your purchase of a Karla Security Android. By listening to this announcement, you have acknowledged your agreement to all terms and conditions. (SPEEDS UP TO AN

RATE) If you are in any way dissatisfied with this product, please return it, along with all packaging, to the Gizmonics Institute, Seventeen Twenty-Five Slough Avenue, Scranton, Pennsylvania, marked “For the Attention of Dr Clayton Forrester”. All postal charges will be refunded upon the isolation of the relevant malfunction.
FX: A SMALL BANG, AND KARLA ONE DEACTIVATES.
Dammit!
It really is a privilege, seeing an expert at the height of his powers.
Right, Karla One is officially offline. We’1ll have to complete the mission with just two Karlas.
We only really need them to transport the drill. There won’t be any risk.
I’d sooner have armed backup and not need it than need armed backup and not have it. Wouldn’t you?
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 5: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS LANDING BONG. ACE ENTERS.
So we've landed, right? (NO ANSWER) We’ve landed, right?
Doctor, Ace is talking to you. (NO ANSWER)
Professor, Mel’s talking to you about how I’m talking to you.
One at a time, please! I just want to see what’s outside.
FX: SCANNER SCREEN OPENS.
Well, so long as the scanner’s working properly, it looks like a forest. It’s beautiful.
And largely untouched by humanity, even in 2085.
So we know the year and the planet. Do you want to narrow it down any further?
Motuo, China. Happy now?
FX: VIEWING SCREEN CLOSES AGAIN.
Not until your spot of unfinished business gets finished.
Anyone would think you didn’t have any confidence in me.
Yeah. Funny, that.
FX: TARDIS DOORS OPEN.
Neither of you have to come with me, you know. I just need to have a quick chat with someone, and we can be on our way. You won’t even have to get changed, Mel.
I already did change!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 10
Did you? Never mind. Back in two shakes, possibly three.
We’ll wait here. I want to practice my Spanish verbs, anyway.
Hold on, Professor, I’m coming with you.
Ace!
What?
What were we just talking about?
I want to make sure he gets back alright. Don’t conjugate any verbs without me.
FX: ACE AND THE DOCTOR LEAVE, THE DOOR CLOSES BEHIND THEM.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 6: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — OUTSIDE THE TARDIS
FX: THE DOCTOR PULLS THE DOOR SHUT.
What were you two talking about?
Girl stuff. Boys, shoes, nails, the usual. Which way?
Come along.
FX: THEY SET OFF.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 7: INT. GORRISTER’S JET — FLIGHT DECK
FX: THE JET CONTINUALLY SWOOPS, RUTH LOSES HER FOOTING.
Whoa!
Try to stay right way up, will you?
Do we absolutely have to fly this low over the treetops?
I thought it was a privilege to see an expert at work.
Do you want to know what I think?
You haven’t had an unexpressed thought since we took off.
I think you’re being deliberately reckless to try to scare me.
You really think I’m that petty?
Frankly-
FX: THE JET SMACKS A TREE BRANCH AND KEEPS GOING.
Whoah-ho-ho! Bit too low that time! (LAUGHS AND HOOTS)
(SOTTO) Just keep telling yourself it’s for the good of humanity, Ruth.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 13
SCENE 8: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
FX: THE DOCTOR AND ACE FIGHT THEIR WAY THROUGH.
I get the impression you and Mel aren’t overly keen on my making this quick stop.
Only because your quick stops tend to involve some all-powerful Time Lord weapon you left on Earth by accident, like the Foot of Omega, or something.
I told you, you needn’t have come.
Ever heard of Pavlov, Professor?
He was never the same when his dog disappeared off after Schroedinger’s Cat. They named the Pavlova after him to try and cheer him up, but it was no good, he was inconsolable.
Yeah, I’m pretty sure none of that happened. But he discovered Pavlovian response, right?
It would have been awkward if someone else had discovered it; that would’ve meant changing the name.
Well, my Pavlovian response is to expect you to get into trouble every time you say you don’t expect any trouble.
But I don’t expect any trouble.
And there I go again.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 9: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: MEL MARCHES IN.
What is the point of buying Spanish language tapes when the
automatically puts them into English? I mean, how is it useful for me to know that “Yes, I would like a Sangria” translates as “Yes, I would like a Sangria”?
FX: SHE FLICKS SWITCHES ON THE CONSOLE.
Come on, one of these buttons must turn off the telepathic circuits, which one is it?
FX: SCANNER SCREEN OPENS.
No, I don’t want to see what’s on the monitor, that’s not even the right switch! How can you have two controls that do the same thing?
FX: ONSCREEN, THE JET PASSES OVERHEAD.
What was that? A plane coming into land.. Why do I get the impression this is the sort of trouble Ace was talking about?
FX: TARDIS DOORS OPEN.
I’m going to regret this. What am I saying? I already regret
it!
FX: SHE MARCHES OUT. DOORS CLOSE.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 15
SCENE 10: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
FX: ACE AND THE DOCTOR FIGHT THEIR WAY THROUGH.
You saw that plane, right?
A P-One Thousand Bowhead stealth jet, powered by slush hydrogen. I thought they were still in the testing stages at this point.
Were you expecting it?
No.
So.. this is a bad thing?
Into each life some rain must fall. Why do you think I carry an umbrella?
FX: THEY ENTER A CLEARING.
Now... tell me what you think of this.
Looks like a load of ruins.
Archaeologists have speculated that it was once a temple, built before recorded time to honour a god no-one can even remember.
FX: BUTTERFLY FLITS PAST.
So what was the- (DISTRACTED BY BUTTERFLY) Clear off!
What is it, Ace?
A butterfly, right in my face!
Don’t swat it, you’ll start a tidal wave!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page
SCENE 11: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
FX: BUTTERFLY’S WINGS FLAPPING HEAVILY ONSCREEN.
(D; ONSCREEN, FINISHING HIS THOUGHT) Or is it “prevent a hurricane”? I can never remember.
Intruders! We are discovered!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 12: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — TEMPLE (CONT)
What about this little building here? A chapel, maybe?
Very close, but completely wrong. It’s actually a lift.
A 1ift? Made out of stone?
Just the natural results of the passing millennia. Let’s get it working again.
FX: SONIC SCREWDRIVER WHIRRS. STONE FALLS FROM THE LIFT IN
CHUNKS. ITS DOORS SLIDE OPEN.
It’s metal underneath!
Of a sort. Shall we be going?
What, inside there?
Les Only ia: litt.
A lift that hasn’t been used in so long the outside’s turned to stone.
There’s no shame in being afraid, you know.
FX: THE BUTTERFLY FLITS CLOSER.
I hope you know how to press the buttons in there as well as you press mine. (DISTRACTED BY THE BUTTERFLY) Get out of it!
Leave it alone, Ace. It’s about as harmless as- well, as another butterfly.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 13: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
Replay that last segment!
FX: THE BUTTERFLY’S WINGS FLAPPING HEAVILY ONSCREEN & DIALOGUE
FROM THE PREVIOUS SCREEN IS REPLAYED FOLLOWED BY NEW LINES.
(D; ONSCREEN) I hope you know how to press the buttons in there as well as you press mine, Professor. Get out of it!
(D) Leave it alone, Ace. It’s about as harmless as- well, as another butterfly. In you go.
FX: ONSCREEN, THEY ENTER THE LIFT.
(D) Next floor, menswear. Going down!
FX: ONSCREEN, THE DOORS CLOSE.
Mute!
Who is “the Professor”?
And what was that device in his hand?
It may have been constructed to provide protection against precipitation.
His other hand, Avvox!
A- a sonic tool of some sort. Chordok would know better than I.
We have planned for too long for any unexpected intrusions!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 19
SCENE 14: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
FX: MEL FIGHTS HER WAY THROUGH.
(A LOUD HISS) Doctor? Ace? Are you anywhere about? (SOTTO) What am I doing? What are any of us doing? I’m just as likely to bump into whoever [was flying that-] (BREAKS OFF)
FX: OVER ABOVE, KARLA TWO’S FOOTSTEPS.
Doctor, is that you?
FX: KARLA TWO GRABS MEL.
CHOKES AS SHE’S HELD BY KARLA TWO
Please do not struggle. It is not my intention to exert the pressure sufficient to break your hyoid bone, but I may do so accidentally.
(CHOKING) You’re- You’re a robot!
The correct term is Security Android. I am designated Karla Two. What is your designation?
I don’t have a designation, just a name. Melanie. Mel.
Which is correct, Melanie or Mel?
You can choose whichever you like if you just loosen your grip!
Very well.
(CAN BREATHE AGAIN) Whew!
I select Mel for speed of pronunciation and to preserve power.
Good idea. Keep your strength up. Look at you! You look magnificent, and so shiny! I can see my reflection in you.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 20
You must come with me. My commander will wish to speak to you.
I don’t seem to have much of a choice, do I?
No.
FX: KARLA TWO DRAGS MEL.
Easy, easy! So... Karla, was it?
Karla Two.
Karla Two. No point in asking if there are any more at home like you, then. Where were you made? Not here, or you’d be speaking Chinese. Oh wait, the telepathic circuits. Forget what I said.
My memory capacity is at seventy-two per cent, I am incapable of forgetting. And I am speaking English.
So who do you belong to? What’s the name of this commander?
That information is restricted.
Then should you really be taking me to see him? You could just forget you ever saw me.
My memory capacity-
I know, seventy-two per cent.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 21
SCENE 15: INT. SILURIAN LIFT
FX: LIFT GRADUALLY DESCENDS.
Anyway, I dispersed the Key to Time throughout the Universe, so the Black Guardian couldn’t get his hands on it again. What do you think of that, Ace?
What do I think of what? You haven’t said anything for twenty
minutes, then you pipe up with “Anyway, I dispersed the Key to Time throughout the Universe”. What am I supposed to think of
that?
Really? I must’ve just thought the other parts. Pity you’re not telepathic, Ace, you would’ve found it very vivid, especially the sword fights.
I bet. You know, Professor, these are the times you just don’t get back.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 16: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — OUTSIDE THE JET
This is a waste of time, Gorrister.
That’s what I said.
Sending Karla Two off, I mean. She only detected a- a field mouse, or whatever they have in this part of the world.
We have a saying in my profession: better safe than mown down by a firing squad.
Sane people have a similar saying. Look, Karla Three can’t manage the drill on her own, can she?
Its weight exceeds my power specifications.
You see? Call her back.
FX: KARLA TWO AND MEL APPROACH THROUGH THE UNDERGROWTH.
No need, that’s her heading back now.
Ouch!
With company.
Er, hello.
Who are you?
Her name is Mel.
Who are you working for?
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 23

I’m not working for anyone, I’m sort of between employers. Quite a long way between, really. Can you tell your android let me go, please? I’m not armed, and she is. That thing on arm is a gun, isn’t it?
Let her go, Karla. (BEAT) Why didn’t that work?
Karla Two, release her.
FX: KARLA TWO LETS HER GO.
Have to remember the number, right. Did Chairman Falco send you, Mel?
Falco? No.
She could be working for Director Shen. She said she was a freelancer.
I didn’t actually say that.
Well, are you a freelancer, or aren’t you?
I work mainly with computers.
Cyber-espionage. Like it.
You do? Good. Does that mean I can go?
Oh, hell no. No, it’d be a lot safer if we just killed you.
to her
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 17: INT. SILURIAN LIFT
FX: LIFT DESCENDS.
So anyway, when the streetlamps came back on, I was hopping onto the bus, and he was left holding the chicken.
Eh?
Now you know what it feels like to come in on the end of a story.
Oh, a chicken! I was picturing a mongoose for some reason. Yes, a chicken makes much more sense.
You can’t read my mind.
You’d like to think that, wouldn’t you?
So what am I thinking now?
Wash your mind out with soap, young lady!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 25
SCENE 18: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
FX: GORRISTER, RUTH, MEL AND TWO KARLAS MARCH. A REGULAR
BLEEPING FROM RUTH’S WRISTPAD.
We should’ve killed her.
“We” are not killing anyone. Wristpad says twenty degrees to the left, everyone.
Every second she’s alive is a threat to this mission. You want my assistance, Ruth, but you won’t take my advice.
No, I won’t. And don’t call me Ruth. We’re not friends, Gorrister.
Is it all right if I call you Ruth? Because I’d just like to say I am delighted that you’re the one giving the orders.
Yeah, I’m just here to do the heavy lifting.
Seems like the Karlas are the ones doing the lifting. What is that thing they’re carrying? It looks like an enormous drill.
There’s a good reason for that.
FX: THE BEEPING INTENSIFIES.
This is it! This is the place!
The place for what?
FX: THEY ENTER THE CLEARING.
The place where I show you just what we’re doing and why we’re
doing, 1.
These look like the ruins of a temple!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 26
So it would seem.
I thought the whole point of this exercise was so no-one knew we were doing it.
Ideally, but she’s here now. I’m going to present my results to the leaders of both blocs simultaneously. What does it matter if she’s working for Falco or Shen?
What if I’m working for neither?
She can report back to her masters that what we do here, we do for the good of mankind. Karlas Two and Three, set the drill down right there.
FX: DRILL IS SET DOWN.
So you’re planning to bore down through the Earth?
Should probably take a few hours. I hope you brought a book to pass the time, Mel.
Why don’t you just use the lift?
What lift?
Right behind you. It certainly looks like a lift.
My God!
This is impossible.
(TO MEL) You don’t look surprised.
You travel with the Doctor for long enough, you get used to the
impossible.
FX: FLUTTERING.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 27
Doctor Wh- (SNEEZES)
Allergies, Professor Drexler?
No, a butterfly just landed on my nose!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 28
SCENE 19: INT. SILURIAN CITY
FX: DOORS OPEN AND THE DOCTOR AND ACE STEP OUT OF THE LIFT.
The buildings... they’re like bubbles, blown out of the rock. They go on forever.
Welcome to the world beneath the world, Ace.
How long has this place been here?
Long before the first of your ancestors crawled out of sea. Contrary to my advice, incidentally.
Aliens were living under our feet all this time?
Some people called this place Shambhala. To the Nazis, it was New Schwabia. Edgar Rice Burroughs knew it as Pellucidar.
What do you call it?
FX: LIFT BEGINS TO RISE AGAIN.
Professor, is the lift going back up automatically, or did someone call it?
The latter, I think.
Since you weren’t expecting anyone to fly in, I’m going to go ahead and guess that this isn’t part of your brilliant plan, either.
I could tell you that it is, but you wouldn’t believe me.
Maybe you can read my mind.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 20: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
FX: BUTTERFLY’S WINGS FLAPPING HEAVILY ONSCREEN & DIALOGUE
FROM THE PREVIOUS SCREEN IS REPLAYED.
This is impossible.
(TO MEL) You don’t look surprised.
You travel with the Doctor for long enough, you get used to the impossible.
The Doctor!
Doctor Wh- (SNEEZES)
Allergies, Prof-
Pause playback!
FX: RECORDING FREEZES.
The Professor and the Doctor. The same being?
He has altered his appearance more than once, Avvox. We are too close to completion to permit his interference. Measures must be taken!
FX: HE ACTIVATES A CONTROL.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 21: INT. SILURIAN CITY
In the time we’ve been waiting we could’ve explored this whole place and been back.
Patience is a virtue, Ace, as well as an opera. Don’t you want to find out who else is interested in the city?
FX: LIFT ARRIVES.
The only person I want to see walk out of that lift is-
FX: LIFT DOORS OPEN.
Mel!
Hello, you two.
Ola, Mel.
That’s not fair, why doesn’t it translate when you say it?
My TARDIS, my rules.
FX: MEL, RUTH, GORRISTER AND THE KARLAS STEP OUT OF LIFT.
You weren’t joking about this place, were you, Ruth?
This is Gorrister, that’s Professor Drexler, and these are two robots called Karla.
A pleasure to meet you all, especially the Karlas. Wonderful design, very Fritz Lang.
Seems as though you know as much about this place as I do, Doctor.
More, I’ll bet.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 31
This way, if memory serves.
This way for what?
The parliament of the Silurians.
FX: ALL START WALKING.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 32
SCENE 22: INT. DEEPER INTO SILURIAN CITY
FX: FADE UP AS ALL WALK ON.
So we're just trusting everyone now?
It’s us who should have trust issues; you’re the one with the guns. I mean, the robots with guns on their arms.
Which is actually dead cool, by the way.
(SIMULTANEOUSLY ) KARLA TWO: KARLA THREE: Thank-you. Thank-you.
Watch your step, the Silurians didn’t believe in railings, and it’s a long way down.
What are the Silurians?
Have I not mentioned them before?
I'd have remembered.
Many millions of years ago, this was their capital city. That rather imposing structure was their parliament building.
Right (SPITS ON HER HANDS), who wants to help me get those doors open?
Not so fast, Ace. They might be electrified.
Not very sociable.
Karla Two, Karla Three, get those doors open.
Synchronise, Karla Three.
Synchronised, Karla Two.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 33
FX: THEY PUSH THE HEAVY DOORS OPEN.
Nice work. C’mon, let’s go inside.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 34
SCENE 23: INT. PARLIAMENT HALL (CONT)
FX: THEY ENTER THE HALL.
No electrical discharge detected.
Odd. I would’ve expected some type of security measure.
Why? The people who built this can’t still be alive... Can they?
It’s beautiful! So smooth and... big.
Pretty tall were they, these Silurians?
What makes you think that, Ace?
Why else would they have made the ceilings so high?
Oh, that would have been to accommodate their pets.
FX: APPROACHING RAPIDLY, THE STOMP OF A TYRANNOSURUS-TYPE
DINOSAUR.
What kind of pets?
Dinosaurs.
FX: THE DINOSAUR ROARS.
Oh my God!
MUSIC: CLOSING THEME
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 35

parts.searchable_dialogue:
MEL: What do you mean, “change of plans”, Ace? I thought we were going to Maruthea.
ACE: Not since the Professor got that look in his eyes and said, “Actually, Ace, it’s just occurred to me, I’ve got some unfinished business to attend to.” Then he starts pushing buttons on the console.
MEL: So?
ACE: So, Mel, it seemed like when you left the first time, and I came on board, he suddenly had plenty of unfinished business to attend to.
MEL: If you’d lived nine hundred years, you’d probably leave a few loose ends dangling here and there.
ACE: Yeah, but your loose ends probably include forgetting to bring the washing in before you went off in the TARDIS.
MEL: I never forget anything. Unfortunately.
ACE: His loose ends are all about half-finished battles with old enemies: Daleks, Cybermen, Fenric.
MEL: What’s a Fenric?
ACE: You need to be on your guard when he starts behaving like this. Things could get dangerous.
MEL: That’s always true when you’re around the Doctor. Danger’s his middle name. Or possibly his first or last name. I can’t believe I’ve never asked him about that, actually.
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 3
ACE: Whatever you ask him now, you won’t get an answer. That’s not who the Doctor is now. He’s a lot more secretive. Maybe he always was, and you just didn’t notice because, well...
MEL: Because what?
ACE: Because he was being secretive.
MEL: There was a time in Pompeii. But he was only keeping things from me because-
ACE: (INTERRUPTING) He didn’t want you to get hurt. But you did get hurt, didn’t you?
MEL: Everybody got hurt; it was Pompeii.
ACE: Fine, ask him for yourself. See how straight he is with you.
MEL: Maybe I should.
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 4
MEL: SCENE 2: INT. GORRISTER’S JET — FLIGHT DECK
LASER: DEVICE GIVES A SMALL ZAP.
GORRISTER: Let’s see if that does the trick.
GORRISTER: Dammit!
RUTH: Shouldn’t you be at the controls, Gorrister?
GORRISTER: Not until we’re over Eastern Bloc airspace and I have to dodge the tracking systems. In the meantime, I’m trying to get the Karlas to function properly.
RUTH: Don’t tell me you don’t approve of female-gendered robot soldiers.
GORRISTER: I don’t approve of anything we’re doing on this mission, Professor.
RUTH: That’s the difference between you and me. I don’t see this as a mission. It’s just something I have to do, so I’m doing it.
GORRISTER: Sounds like a mission to me. One that’d have Chairman Falco tearing his wig off if he knew about it.
RUTH: But he won’t know about it, will he? That’s why you’re here, as my expert on stealth. The Chairman’1l know what he needs to, when I’m ready to tell him.
GORRISTER: Beats me why you won’t trust him.
RUTH: Oh, don’t tell me; you voted for him.
GORRISTER: I like him. He says what’s on his mind.
GORRISTER: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 5
RUTH: We can all do that. Your moustache makes you look like my old P.E. Teacher, and she was nothing to write home about. See how easy that was?
GORRISTER: It’s going to be a long flight to Motuo if all you’re planning on doing is insulting me.
RUTH: Can’t the big macho man take it?
GORRISTER: You called me, Professor Drexler, because I am a big macho man.
RUTH: I called you because you owe me a massive debt.
GORRISTER: One that could get me shot by the Western Bloc for treason. Or by the Eastern Bloc for spying.
RUTH: Seems to me, the petulant Frank Gorrister is nearly as unattractive as the tough Frank Gorrister.
GORRISTER: Have you ever thought that maybe you just don’t like men?
RUTH: I don’t like two particular types of men, the sensitive and the senseless.
GORRISTER: That doesn’t leave a lot of wiggle room in between.
RUTH: Then perhaps mankind should take a long, hard look at itself.
RUTH: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 6
RUTH: SCENE 3: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
DOCTOR: (PERFORMING A “DANGEROUS DAN McGREW”-STYLE RECITATION AS HE WORKS) “When through the bar doors burst Abslom Daak, a snarl upon his face; And said to the landlord I’m here to kill, every Dalek in the place...”
MEL: Doctor...
DOCTOR: Yes, Mel?
MEL: Ace says we've changed course.
DOCTOR: Does she?
MEL: Well?
DOCTOR: Well, what?
MEL: Have we changed course?
DOCTOR: Yes.
MEL: Where are we going?
DOCTOR: Somewhere else. That’s where you usually go when you change course.
MEL: And where is somewhere else?
DOCTOR: Home.
MEL: Home? We’re going to Gallifrey?
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 7
DOCTOR: Not my home, Mel. A few more oceans are going to have to flow under a few more bridges before I’1l be welcome back there.
MEL: So my home, then. Earth.
DOCTOR: That is your home, isn’t it? Unless I’ve been misinformed.
MEL: When?
DOCTOR: When we first met, I suppose.
MEL: No, I mean what year are we heading for?
DOCTOR: About a century after your time. Many things have changed, many others have remained the same.
MEL: Funny how that happens. So is there a reason for the diversion?
DOCTOR: Does there have to be?
MEL: No, it’s just that- Well, I’m dressed for a party. I’d like to know if I’ve got to change.
DOCTOR: I often think that would be nice, too. Though in my case, the changes are usually more than just fashion-related.
MEL: So are we going to a party or not?
DOCTOR: Not a party, no. There’s just something I have to take care of.
MEL: Should I be concerned?
DOCTOR: I don’t think so, Mel. It shouldn’t take more than an hour. But the effects might last until the end of the world.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 8
DOCTOR: SCENE 4: INT. GORRISTER’S JET — FLIGHT DECK
RUTH: Anything I can do to help? Mop your brow? Offer words of positive reinforcement?
GORRISTER: No need. Nearly got- Ha!
KARLA ONE: Congratulations on your purchase of a Karla Security Android. By listening to this announcement, you have acknowledged your agreement to all terms and conditions. (SPEEDS UP TO AN
INCOHERENT: RATE) If you are in any way dissatisfied with this product, please return it, along with all packaging, to the Gizmonics Institute, Seventeen Twenty-Five Slough Avenue, Scranton, Pennsylvania, marked “For the Attention of Dr Clayton Forrester”. All postal charges will be refunded upon the isolation of the relevant malfunction.
GORRISTER: Dammit!
RUTH: It really is a privilege, seeing an expert at the height of his powers.
GORRISTER: Right, Karla One is officially offline. We’1ll have to complete the mission with just two Karlas.
RUTH: We only really need them to transport the drill. There won’t be any risk.
GORRISTER: I’d sooner have armed backup and not need it than need armed backup and not have it. Wouldn’t you?
GORRISTER: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 9
GORRISTER: SCENE 5: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
ACE: So we've landed, right? (NO ANSWER) We’ve landed, right?
MEL: Doctor, Ace is talking to you. (NO ANSWER)
ACE: Professor, Mel’s talking to you about how I’m talking to you.
DOCTOR: One at a time, please! I just want to see what’s outside.
MEL: Well, so long as the scanner’s working properly, it looks like a forest. It’s beautiful.
DOCTOR: And largely untouched by humanity, even in 2085.
ACE: So we know the year and the planet. Do you want to narrow it down any further?
DOCTOR: Motuo, China. Happy now?
ACE: Not until your spot of unfinished business gets finished.
DOCTOR: Anyone would think you didn’t have any confidence in me.
ACE: Yeah. Funny, that.
DOCTOR: Neither of you have to come with me, you know. I just need to have a quick chat with someone, and we can be on our way. You won’t even have to get changed, Mel.
MEL: I already did change!
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 10
DOCTOR: Did you? Never mind. Back in two shakes, possibly three.
MEL: We’ll wait here. I want to practice my Spanish verbs, anyway.
ACE: Hold on, Professor, I’m coming with you.
MEL: Ace!
ACE: What?
MEL: What were we just talking about?
ACE: I want to make sure he gets back alright. Don’t conjugate any verbs without me.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 11
ACE: SCENE 6: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — OUTSIDE THE TARDIS
DOCTOR: What were you two talking about?
ACE: Girl stuff. Boys, shoes, nails, the usual. Which way?
DOCTOR: Come along.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 12
DOCTOR: SCENE 7: INT. GORRISTER’S JET — FLIGHT DECK
RUTH: Whoa!
GORRISTER: Try to stay right way up, will you?
RUTH: Do we absolutely have to fly this low over the treetops?
GORRISTER: I thought it was a privilege to see an expert at work.
RUTH: Do you want to know what I think?
GORRISTER: You haven’t had an unexpressed thought since we took off.
RUTH: I think you’re being deliberately reckless to try to scare me.
GORRISTER: You really think I’m that petty?
RUTH: Frankly-
GORRISTER: Whoah-ho-ho! Bit too low that time! (LAUGHS AND HOOTS)
RUTH: (SOTTO) Just keep telling yourself it’s for the good of humanity, Ruth.
RUTH: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 13
RUTH: SCENE 8: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
DOCTOR: I get the impression you and Mel aren’t overly keen on my making this quick stop.
ACE: Only because your quick stops tend to involve some all-powerful Time Lord weapon you left on Earth by accident, like the Foot of Omega, or something.
DOCTOR: I told you, you needn’t have come.
ACE: Ever heard of Pavlov, Professor?
DOCTOR: He was never the same when his dog disappeared off after Schroedinger’s Cat. They named the Pavlova after him to try and cheer him up, but it was no good, he was inconsolable.
ACE: Yeah, I’m pretty sure none of that happened. But he discovered Pavlovian response, right?
DOCTOR: It would have been awkward if someone else had discovered it; that would’ve meant changing the name.
ACE: Well, my Pavlovian response is to expect you to get into trouble every time you say you don’t expect any trouble.
DOCTOR: But I don’t expect any trouble.
ACE: And there I go again.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 14
ACE: SCENE 9: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
MEL: What is the point of buying Spanish language tapes when the
TARDIS: automatically puts them into English? I mean, how is it useful for me to know that “Yes, I would like a Sangria” translates as “Yes, I would like a Sangria”?
MEL: Come on, one of these buttons must turn off the telepathic circuits, which one is it?
MEL: No, I don’t want to see what’s on the monitor, that’s not even the right switch! How can you have two controls that do the same thing?
MEL: What was that? A plane coming into land.. Why do I get the impression this is the sort of trouble Ace was talking about?
MEL: I’m going to regret this. What am I saying? I already regret
MEL: it!
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 15
MEL: SCENE 10: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
ACE: You saw that plane, right?
DOCTOR: A P-One Thousand Bowhead stealth jet, powered by slush hydrogen. I thought they were still in the testing stages at this point.
ACE: Were you expecting it?
DOCTOR: No.
ACE: So.. this is a bad thing?
DOCTOR: Into each life some rain must fall. Why do you think I carry an umbrella?
DOCTOR: Now... tell me what you think of this.
ACE: Looks like a load of ruins.
DOCTOR: Archaeologists have speculated that it was once a temple, built before recorded time to honour a god no-one can even remember.
ACE: So what was the- (DISTRACTED BY BUTTERFLY) Clear off!
DOCTOR: What is it, Ace?
ACE: A butterfly, right in my face!
DOCTOR: Don’t swat it, you’ll start a tidal wave!
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page
DOCTOR: SCENE 11: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
DOCTOR: (D; ONSCREEN, FINISHING HIS THOUGHT) Or is it “prevent a hurricane”? I can never remember.
SPENODUS: Intruders! We are discovered!
SPENODUS: 16
SPENODUS: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 17
SPENODUS: SCENE 12: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — TEMPLE (CONT)
ACE: What about this little building here? A chapel, maybe?
DOCTOR: Very close, but completely wrong. It’s actually a lift.
ACE: A 1ift? Made out of stone?
DOCTOR: Just the natural results of the passing millennia. Let’s get it working again.
DOCTOR: CHUNKS. ITS DOORS SLIDE OPEN.
ACE: It’s metal underneath!
DOCTOR: Of a sort. Shall we be going?
ACE: What, inside there?
DOCTOR: Les Only ia: litt.
ACE: A lift that hasn’t been used in so long the outside’s turned to stone.
DOCTOR: There’s no shame in being afraid, you know.
ACE: I hope you know how to press the buttons in there as well as you press mine. (DISTRACTED BY THE BUTTERFLY) Get out of it!
DOCTOR: Leave it alone, Ace. It’s about as harmless as- well, as another butterfly.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 18
DOCTOR: SCENE 13: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
SPENODUS: Replay that last segment!
SPENODUS: FROM THE PREVIOUS SCREEN IS REPLAYED FOLLOWED BY NEW LINES.
ACE: (D; ONSCREEN) I hope you know how to press the buttons in there as well as you press mine, Professor. Get out of it!
DOCTOR: (D) Leave it alone, Ace. It’s about as harmless as- well, as another butterfly. In you go.
DOCTOR: (D) Next floor, menswear. Going down!
SPENODUS: Mute!
AVVOX: Who is “the Professor”?
SPENODUS: And what was that device in his hand?
AVVOX: It may have been constructed to provide protection against precipitation.
SPENODUS: His other hand, Avvox!
AVVOX: A- a sonic tool of some sort. Chordok would know better than I.
SPENODUS: We have planned for too long for any unexpected intrusions!
SPENODUS: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 19
SPENODUS: SCENE 14: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
MEL: (A LOUD HISS) Doctor? Ace? Are you anywhere about? (SOTTO) What am I doing? What are any of us doing? I’m just as likely to bump into whoever [was flying that-] (BREAKS OFF)
MEL: Doctor, is that you?
KARLA TWO: Please do not struggle. It is not my intention to exert the pressure sufficient to break your hyoid bone, but I may do so accidentally.
MEL: (CHOKING) You’re- You’re a robot!
KARLA TWO: The correct term is Security Android. I am designated Karla Two. What is your designation?
MEL: I don’t have a designation, just a name. Melanie. Mel.
KARLA TWO: Which is correct, Melanie or Mel?
MEL: You can choose whichever you like if you just loosen your grip!
KARLA TWO: Very well.
MEL: (CAN BREATHE AGAIN) Whew!
KARLA TWO: I select Mel for speed of pronunciation and to preserve power.
MEL: Good idea. Keep your strength up. Look at you! You look magnificent, and so shiny! I can see my reflection in you.
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 20
KARLA TWO: You must come with me. My commander will wish to speak to you.
MEL: I don’t seem to have much of a choice, do I?
KARLA TWO: No.
MEL: Easy, easy! So... Karla, was it?
KARLA TWO: Karla Two.
MEL: Karla Two. No point in asking if there are any more at home like you, then. Where were you made? Not here, or you’d be speaking Chinese. Oh wait, the telepathic circuits. Forget what I said.
KARLA TWO: My memory capacity is at seventy-two per cent, I am incapable of forgetting. And I am speaking English.
MEL: So who do you belong to? What’s the name of this commander?
KARLA TWO: That information is restricted.
MEL: Then should you really be taking me to see him? You could just forget you ever saw me.
KARLA TWO: My memory capacity-
MEL: I know, seventy-two per cent.
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 21
MEL: SCENE 15: INT. SILURIAN LIFT
DOCTOR: Anyway, I dispersed the Key to Time throughout the Universe, so the Black Guardian couldn’t get his hands on it again. What do you think of that, Ace?
ACE: What do I think of what? You haven’t said anything for twenty
ACE: minutes, then you pipe up with “Anyway, I dispersed the Key to Time throughout the Universe”. What am I supposed to think of
ACE: that?
DOCTOR: Really? I must’ve just thought the other parts. Pity you’re not telepathic, Ace, you would’ve found it very vivid, especially the sword fights.
ACE: I bet. You know, Professor, these are the times you just don’t get back.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 22
ACE: SCENE 16: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — OUTSIDE THE JET
RUTH: This is a waste of time, Gorrister.
GORRISTER: That’s what I said.
RUTH: Sending Karla Two off, I mean. She only detected a- a field mouse, or whatever they have in this part of the world.
GORRISTER: We have a saying in my profession: better safe than mown down by a firing squad.
RUTH: Sane people have a similar saying. Look, Karla Three can’t manage the drill on her own, can she?
KARLA THREE: Its weight exceeds my power specifications.
RUTH: You see? Call her back.
GORRISTER: No need, that’s her heading back now.
MEL: Ouch!
GORRISTER: With company.
MEL: Er, hello.
RUTH: Who are you?
KARLA TWO: Her name is Mel.
GORRISTER: Who are you working for?
GORRISTER: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 23
MEL: I’m not working for anyone, I’m sort of between employers. Quite a long way between, really. Can you tell your android let me go, please? I’m not armed, and she is. That thing on arm is a gun, isn’t it?
RUTH: Let her go, Karla. (BEAT) Why didn’t that work?
GORRISTER: Karla Two, release her.
RUTH: Have to remember the number, right. Did Chairman Falco send you, Mel?
MEL: Falco? No.
GORRISTER: She could be working for Director Shen. She said she was a freelancer.
MEL: I didn’t actually say that.
GORRISTER: Well, are you a freelancer, or aren’t you?
MEL: I work mainly with computers.
GORRISTER: Cyber-espionage. Like it.
MEL: You do? Good. Does that mean I can go?
GORRISTER: Oh, hell no. No, it’d be a lot safer if we just killed you.
GORRISTER: to her
GORRISTER: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 24
GORRISTER: SCENE 17: INT. SILURIAN LIFT
ACE: So anyway, when the streetlamps came back on, I was hopping onto the bus, and he was left holding the chicken.
DOCTOR: Eh?
ACE: Now you know what it feels like to come in on the end of a story.
DOCTOR: Oh, a chicken! I was picturing a mongoose for some reason. Yes, a chicken makes much more sense.
ACE: You can’t read my mind.
DOCTOR: You’d like to think that, wouldn’t you?
ACE: So what am I thinking now?
DOCTOR: Wash your mind out with soap, young lady!
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 25
DOCTOR: SCENE 18: EXT. MOTUO JUNGLE — UNDERGROWTH
DOCTOR: BLEEPING FROM RUTH’S WRISTPAD.
GORRISTER: We should’ve killed her.
RUTH: “We” are not killing anyone. Wristpad says twenty degrees to the left, everyone.
GORRISTER: Every second she’s alive is a threat to this mission. You want my assistance, Ruth, but you won’t take my advice.
RUTH: No, I won’t. And don’t call me Ruth. We’re not friends, Gorrister.
MEL: Is it all right if I call you Ruth? Because I’d just like to say I am delighted that you’re the one giving the orders.
GORRISTER: Yeah, I’m just here to do the heavy lifting.
MEL: Seems like the Karlas are the ones doing the lifting. What is that thing they’re carrying? It looks like an enormous drill.
RUTH: There’s a good reason for that.
RUTH: This is it! This is the place!
MEL: The place for what?
RUTH: The place where I show you just what we’re doing and why we’re
RUTH: doing, 1.
MEL: These look like the ruins of a temple!
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 26
RUTH: So it would seem.
GORRISTER: I thought the whole point of this exercise was so no-one knew we were doing it.
RUTH: Ideally, but she’s here now. I’m going to present my results to the leaders of both blocs simultaneously. What does it matter if she’s working for Falco or Shen?
MEL: What if I’m working for neither?
RUTH: She can report back to her masters that what we do here, we do for the good of mankind. Karlas Two and Three, set the drill down right there.
MEL: So you’re planning to bore down through the Earth?
RUTH: Should probably take a few hours. I hope you brought a book to pass the time, Mel.
MEL: Why don’t you just use the lift?
GORRISTER: What lift?
MEL: Right behind you. It certainly looks like a lift.
GORRISTER: My God!
RUTH: This is impossible.
GORRISTER: (TO MEL) You don’t look surprised.
MEL: You travel with the Doctor for long enough, you get used to the
MEL: impossible.
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 27
RUTH: Doctor Wh- (SNEEZES)
GORRISTER: Allergies, Professor Drexler?
RUTH: No, a butterfly just landed on my nose!
RUTH: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 28
RUTH: SCENE 19: INT. SILURIAN CITY
ACE: The buildings... they’re like bubbles, blown out of the rock. They go on forever.
DOCTOR: Welcome to the world beneath the world, Ace.
ACE: How long has this place been here?
DOCTOR: Long before the first of your ancestors crawled out of sea. Contrary to my advice, incidentally.
ACE: Aliens were living under our feet all this time?
DOCTOR: Some people called this place Shambhala. To the Nazis, it was New Schwabia. Edgar Rice Burroughs knew it as Pellucidar.
ACE: What do you call it?
ACE: Professor, is the lift going back up automatically, or did someone call it?
DOCTOR: The latter, I think.
ACE: Since you weren’t expecting anyone to fly in, I’m going to go ahead and guess that this isn’t part of your brilliant plan, either.
DOCTOR: I could tell you that it is, but you wouldn’t believe me.
ACE: Maybe you can read my mind.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 29
ACE: SCENE 20: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
ACE: FROM THE PREVIOUS SCREEN IS REPLAYED.
RUTH: This is impossible.
GORRISTER: (TO MEL) You don’t look surprised.
MEL: You travel with the Doctor for long enough, you get used to the impossible.
SPENODUS: The Doctor!
RUTH: Doctor Wh- (SNEEZES)
GORRISTER: Allergies, Prof-
AVVOX: Pause playback!
AVVOX: The Professor and the Doctor. The same being?
SPENODUS: He has altered his appearance more than once, Avvox. We are too close to completion to permit his interference. Measures must be taken!
SPENODUS: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 30
SPENODUS: SCENE 21: INT. SILURIAN CITY
ACE: In the time we’ve been waiting we could’ve explored this whole place and been back.
DOCTOR: Patience is a virtue, Ace, as well as an opera. Don’t you want to find out who else is interested in the city?
ACE: The only person I want to see walk out of that lift is-
ACE: Mel!
MEL: Hello, you two.
DOCTOR: Ola, Mel.
MEL: That’s not fair, why doesn’t it translate when you say it?
DOCTOR: My TARDIS, my rules.
GORRISTER: You weren’t joking about this place, were you, Ruth?
MEL: This is Gorrister, that’s Professor Drexler, and these are two robots called Karla.
DOCTOR: A pleasure to meet you all, especially the Karlas. Wonderful design, very Fritz Lang.
RUTH: Seems as though you know as much about this place as I do, Doctor.
ACE: More, I’ll bet.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR: This way, if memory serves.
MEL: This way for what?
DOCTOR: The parliament of the Silurians.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 32
DOCTOR: SCENE 22: INT. DEEPER INTO SILURIAN CITY
GORRISTER: So we're just trusting everyone now?
MEL: It’s us who should have trust issues; you’re the one with the guns. I mean, the robots with guns on their arms.
ACE: Which is actually dead cool, by the way.
ACE: (SIMULTANEOUSLY ) KARLA TWO: KARLA THREE: Thank-you. Thank-you.
RUTH: Watch your step, the Silurians didn’t believe in railings, and it’s a long way down.
MEL: What are the Silurians?
DOCTOR: Have I not mentioned them before?
MEL: I'd have remembered.
DOCTOR: Many millions of years ago, this was their capital city. That rather imposing structure was their parliament building.
ACE: Right (SPITS ON HER HANDS), who wants to help me get those doors open?
DOCTOR: Not so fast, Ace. They might be electrified.
MEL: Not very sociable.
GORRISTER: Karla Two, Karla Three, get those doors open.
KARLA TWO: Synchronise, Karla Three.
KARLA THREE: Synchronised, Karla Two.
KARLA THREE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 33
GORRISTER: Nice work. C’mon, let’s go inside.
GORRISTER: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 34
GORRISTER: SCENE 23: INT. PARLIAMENT HALL (CONT)
KARLA TWO: No electrical discharge detected.
DOCTOR: Odd. I would’ve expected some type of security measure.
MEL: Why? The people who built this can’t still be alive... Can they?
RUTH: It’s beautiful! So smooth and... big.
ACE: Pretty tall were they, these Silurians?
DOCTOR: What makes you think that, Ace?
ACE: Why else would they have made the ceilings so high?
DOCTOR: Oh, that would have been to accommodate their pets.
DOCTOR: DINOSAUR.
GORRISTER: What kind of pets?
DOCTOR: Dinosaurs.
RUTH: Oh my God!
RUTH: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 35

RUTH: Fine. I never thought I’d say this, but there are bigger issues now, though what Falco will do with the information, I can’t imagine. Please don’t tell me you voted for him.

MEL: Ruth, this is incredible! I can’t believe the Doctor’s never mentioned it before.

RUTH: Falco was the Western Bloc’s premier arms manufacturer. He was voted in on a platform of keeping us safe, whatever the cost. I don’t think he ever expected that the cost might be negotiation. It’s probably more painful to him than actually going to war.
ACE: Then why doesn’t he just declare war, if he’s the one in charge?
DOCTOR: Because the one in charge isn’t necessarily the one who wields the power. Not always a bad thing.
ACE: I notice nobody’s asking what happens if Falco turns out to be the body under the sheet.
RUTH: The Silurian capital’s under Eastern Bloc territory, Ace. It’s more likely to be Director Shen. Maybe.
ACE: Just so long as he helps us look for Mel, I could care less-
ACE: BEATING THE OTHER TWO KARLAS.
ACE: Karla One!
KARLA ONE: I am here to rescue you.
RUTH: I thought she’d been destroyed in the crash!
KARLA: FORTY-SEVEN: Please do not attack us, inferior Karla.
KARLA: THIRTY-ONE: There is no apparent benefit to be derived from compromising my
DOCTOR: Karla One, please stop! You’re destroying them! Stop!
DOCTOR: GROUND.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 93
DOCTOR: Oh, well... that’s them all over.
RUTH: Brilliant. Before she tore them to pieces we were just intruders. Now we’re insurrectionists. Karla One, where’ve you been all this time?
KARLA ONE: On the seabed.
ACE: You sank!
KARLA ONE: Affirmative. I was forced to walk here in order to rescue you.
ACE: So now what do we do?
DOCTOR: Now we do the only thing we can, Ace. Karla One... take us to their leader.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 94
DOCTOR: SCENE 64: EXT. FALCO’S RETREAT — LANDING PAD
JODELET: Mr Chairman! I hoped I’d find you
FALCO: Jodelet, how’s my hair looking? I the updraft when Shen lands.
JODELET: No-one would ever know, sir.
FALCO: (DEADLY SERIOUS) Know what?
JODELET: Er, nothing. Mr Chairman, there’s
FALCO: at the pad.
FALCO: don’t want it messed about by
FALCO: been a development.
FALCO: Don’t say she’s delayed, doesn’t she realise how much this matters to- (STOPS HIMSELF) to the whole world?
JODELET: Actually, sir, Director Shen’s craft is due to arrive at landing pad the appointed hour. You’re out at the landing pad a
JODELET: little early.
FALCO: Yeah, I suppose I am. Guess I’m on edge, Jodelet. Peace treaties, negotiations... It’s new to me. I’m not the kind of
FALCO: chairman I thought I'd be.
JODELET: It’s all already been taken care of in advance, sir. This
JODELET: televised event is simply...
FALCO: Propaganda.
JODELET: I would prefer to say “advertising”. But that’s not what I
JODELET: wanted to talk about. I wished to intruders are under guard in your
FALCO: What?
JODELET: let you know that three office.
JODELET: An unregistered Karla, an unknown male and female... and
JODELET: Professor Ruth Drexler.
JODELET: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 95
FALCO: Drexler? The space programme woman? What the hell is she doing here?
JODELET: That’s one of the questions I intend to ask her, Mr Chairman.
FALCO: Forget it! I’m gonna get an explanation out of her! You stay here.
JODELET: But, sir!
FALCO: (DEPARTING) I said stay here!
JODELET: Director Shen-
FALCO: Just fob her off, Jodelet, that’s what you’re good at!
JODELET: (TO SELF) No, what I’m good at is doing all the work and staying in the shadows. Who’s the real leader here?
JODELET: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 96
JODELET: SCENE 65: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — LAB
CHORDOK: Remain still, Mel.
MEL: I wish people would stop saying that to me! Look, Chordok, you don’t need to do this!
CHORDOK: I had hoped not.
MEL: Don’t tell me, you’re just following orders!
CHORDOK: No triad member can give orders to another.
MEL: Just put down that drill and we can talk.
CHORDOK: You have been unwilling to do so without the encouragement of the drill.
MEL: That’s because I don’t know whatever it is you think I know, which means I can’t tell you what it is you want to hear.
CHORDOK: I have no experience of your kind. I therefore cannot know if you are lying to me now.
MEL: The Doctor says I’m as honest as the day is long! And we’ve been to some places with really long days!
CHORDOK: The Doctor has long been an enemy of the my people.
MEL: Look, I’m sure you’re wrong about that.
CHORDOK: What has he told you of his encounters with us?
CHORDOK: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 97
MEL: Well... nothing, actually. But I know the Doctor, and I can promise you that all he ever wants to do is help people.
CHORDOK: The Doctor was a party to the destruction of one of our colonies over a hundred years ago.
MEL: I told you, I don’t know about that, but I’m sure you’re mistaken!
CHORDOK: More recently, he took the lives of an entire military unit using the deadliest poison known to our species.
MEL: That- That doesn’t sound like something he’d do.
CHORDOK: Then perhaps you are incorrect when you claim to know him. To my race, he has brought nothing but death.
CHORDOK: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 98
CHORDOK: SCENE 66: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — OFFICE
FALCO: Lizard people?
RUTH: Silurians.
FALCO: You know, Professor Drexler, my old man used to write “Tlluminati” on every banknote he had. Back when we still used paper money. I thought you of all people had more sense than he did:
RUTH: Mr Chairman, Jodelet must have been briefed you about the Sea Base Four incident.
FALCO: Deranged synch-operator.
RUTH: You know that’s not true.
FALCO: And who are these two?
ACE: I’m Ace, he’s the Doctor.
DOCTOR: Pleased to meet you, Mr Falco.
FALCO: Mr Chairman.
DOCTOR: Mr Chairman — we’re very concerned about our friend, and I wonder if your Karlas here would conduct a search for her?
FALCO: Leaving me defenceless just minutes before the most important summit of our lifetime.
DOCTOR: Well, yes. But with good reason.
FALCO: To look for someone I’ve no way of knowing even exists.
ACE: She exists! I hope.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 99
FALCO: I’ve seen footage of a guy named the Doctor, and he didn’t look anything like you.
DOCTOR: I don’t photograph well, unfortunately.
FALCO: What’s your interest in all this?
DOCTOR: We’re just two innocent bystanders who became swept up in all the excitement. But I can confirm that everything Professor Drexler says is true.
FALCO: Funny thing, Doctor: I don’t believe you. Are you gonna give me the same story, honey?
ACE: I’m not your honey.
FALCO: Spunky! I love it. What I don’t love is having four intruders on this private retreat, one of whom tore apart two very expensive-to-replace Karlas.
KARLA ONE: Their reaction times were considerably below acceptable levels.
DOCTOR: That sounds like a boast, Karla One.
KARLA ONE: It may be interpreted as such, but there can be no intent. My vocabulary is entirely pre-programmed.
FALCO: Are you lot done? Because I can’t spare any more of my valuable time on you. I don’t think any of you appreciate just what I have to do today.
RUTH: We surrendered, Mr Chairman, so we could bring you the evidence.
FALCO: What evidence?
SETTING: DOWN.
SETTING: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 100
JODELET: (D; OVER RADIO) Mr Chairman, I’m at the landing pad. Director Shen’s craft is touching down now! She’1ll no doubt want to see you!
FALCO: In a minute, in a minute!
FALCO: This evidence is supposed to be stored on some wristpad, right?
FALCO: So where’s the wristpad?
RUTH: Mel had it.
RUTH: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 101
RUTH: SCENE 67: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — BRIDGE
RUTH: AVOXX AND SPENODUS’ DIALOGUE.
CHORDOK: (D; OVER COMPUTER) Status update four hundred and twenty-seven. Work has progressed quickly since the last surgery. All difficulties regarding the human subject’s more evolved synapses have been overcome. In a very short space of time, the candidate will once again take their place as leader of the human sect, and the next stage of the triad’s plan to hasten nuclear catastrophe-
AVVOX: This information must be deleted.
SPENODUS: It must all be deleted, Avvox, everything!
AVVOX: I shall notify Chordok.
SPENODUS: Chordok is with the human prisoner. I shall deal with this.
AVVOX: Do you have the technical knowledge, Spenodus?
SPENODUS: I do not need “technical knowledge” to destroy this device.
AVVOX: What do you suppose the humans wanted with the information?
SPENODUS: Irrelevant! Their elimination will begin shortly.
AVVOX: They penetrated our capital, but made no attempt to harm our sleeping brothers.
SPENODUS: They did not have the opportunity, or they were simply an advance party.
AVVOX: But what if-
AVVOX: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 102
SPENODUS: They are enemies of the our people, Avvox! The presence of this Doctor confirms it! He alters his appearance to confuse us, but always his motives are the same: he means to destroy us!
SPENODUS: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 103
SPENODUS: SCENE 68: EXT. FALCO’S RETREAT — LANDING PAD
SHEN: WALKS TOWARDS JODELET.
JODELET: Madam Director, it’s an honour to finally meet you.
SHEN: Where is Chairman Falco, Mr Jodelet?
JODELET: He is unavoidably detained.
SHEN: Detained? This meeting was arranged many months ago, it has been planned down to the very second we are to appear together before the eyes of the world. It is important that we are seen. The people must see.
JODELET: Yes, but.. there was an unexpected incident. A small aircraft crashed, just off the island’s coast.
SHEN: An accident?
JODELET: Oh yes, yes, completely accidental. A freakish coincidence, but... they do sometimes happen.
FALCO: OK, I’m here now. We’re all ready to go.
SHEN: Mr Chairman.
FALCO: Madam Director. I, uh, apologise for the delay-
JODELET: I was just informing Director Shen about the light aircraft that crashed nearby.
FALCO: Oh yeah, that.
SHEN: There were no survivors?
SHEN: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 104
FALCO: Doesn’t look like it, no.
SHEN: Surely you have conducted a search?
FALCO: No-one to do it, Madam Director. It’s just you, me and Jodelet on the island.
JODELET: As per your demands. We retain only a force of security androids.
SHEN: Then perhaps some of them might now be used to search the vicinity for the bodies of the passengers. As you see, I have brought my own security robots.
FALCO: Riiiight. Have you ever thought of something a little more lightweight, Madam Director? Something more like a person and less like a tank?
SHEN: Human beings are unreliable, Chairman.
FALCO: Interesting philosophy.
SHEN: There is still a little time before our joint broadcast. I should like to spend that time in contemplation.
FALCO: Contemplation?
SHEN: I view this opportunity for mutual disarmament as more than mere political expediency; on a purely personal level, it is an act of faith.
FALCO: Faith?
SHEN: I answer to a higher power.
SHEN: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 105
FALCO: Fine, fine. Jodelet here will show you to one of our guest rooms.
SHEN: That will not be necessary. I will remain onboard my craft until required. Until then, Mr Chairman.
FALCO: Well, that’s rude! She doesn’t even seem human! I mean, who talks like that?
JODELET: I do, sir.
FALCO: Yeah, whatever. I’1ll be in my office ‘til she’s got herself sorted out.
JODELET: I hope you didn’t think me presumptuous earlier?
FALCO: Telling her it was an accident, you mean? No, no, that was good thinking. One wrong word right now, and we’ve knackered the whole deal.
JODELET: If you don’t mind mind me asking, sir, where are the prisoners now? There are no cells in the compound.
FALCO: Got a bunch of Karlas guarding them in the library.
JODELET: At least they won’t be bored.
JODELET: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 106
JODELET: SCENE 69: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — LIBRARY
RUTH: None of the books in here look like they’ve ever been read, except for this one... Oh, and look what it is: Falco’s autobiography. Hey, Karlas, think fast!
DOCTOR: Ruth, no!
KARLA NINETEEN: Kindly do not attempt to use works of literature as offensive weapons.
RUTH: Just testing your response times. They’re good, dammit.
DOCTOR: Please try not to rouse them. The same goes for you too, Ace. Stop doing whatever it is you’re doing.
ACE: I’m trying to figure out which of these bookcases has a secret tunnel behind it.
DOCTOR: That’s rather too clichéd for words, isn’t it? Come over here, we need to pool our ideas.
ACE: That all depends on whether we all want the same thing.
RUTH: Is this what you were on about before? I think it’s time you two were honest with me.
DOCTOR: Ace has decided secrecy is the best policy.
ACE: It doesn’t matter now. The three of us stuck here, and even if Mel is still out there somewhere, there’s no way we can get to her.
ACE: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 107
KARLA ONE: Four.
ACE: Four of us stuck here. Sorry, Karla One. So tell her, Professor. Tell her how you were planning on helping the Silurians.
RUTH: What?
ACE: He brought us here because he wanted to give the Earth back to them.
RUTH: Is that true?
DOCTOR: The Silurians didn’t give up their claim to this planet. I hardly think they should be penalised for sleeping in.
ACE: They’re planning on killing the human race!
DOCTOR: Not for the first time. But humanity has tried to wipe them out more than once.
ACE: So how were you planning on doing it?
DOCTOR: It’s just a simple exercise in levelling the playing field, Ace, that’s all.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 108
DOCTOR: SCENE 70: INT. SILURIAN SHIP — LAB
CHORDOK: This is not what I imagined I would find myself doing when I made science my vocation, Mel. But much has happened to this world since that day.
MEL: I understand, Chordok. You’re a man- (CORRECTS SELF) a person of learning. You’re not a torturer.
CHORDOK: I believed that I was not.
MEL: Then don’t let Spenodus turn you into one! You’re a scientist, you have an obligation to the truth!
CHORDOK: You are correct, Mel. Which is why I must make all possible effort to get to the truth.
MEL: Oh, no!
CHORDOK: You will disclose the Doctor’s intentions!
MEL: All right, I didn’t want to have to do this...
MEL: . but stay back or I shoot!
CHORDOK: Where did you acquire that weapon?
MEL: From a robot friend of mine. Now move away from the doorway!
CHORDOK: Much is unknown about the Doctor, but in all our accounts, one thing remains constant. Neither he nor his human companions ever use firearms.
CHORDOK: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 109
MEL: Was that why you didn’t search me? Look, this wasn’t exactly part of my plan, but neither was getting dissected, so out of my way!
CHORDOK: No!
MEL: Oh no! Chordok, I’m so sorry, I didn’t mean for it to go off, I just- Are you alive, please speak to me!
AVVOX: (D; OVER RADIO) Chordok? We heard an explosion, what is happening? Respond, Chordok!
MEL: I hope your pals know how to patch you up, Chordok, I need to get out of here. I’ve got to find the Doctor.
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 110
MEL: SCENE 71: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — LIBRARY
DOCTOR: Honestly, Ace, I really don’t know what you’re getting so upset about.
ACE: Oh, how about because you’ve always stood up for the Earth until now?
DOCTOR: I still am. Just not for the species that happens to be dominant at present. There was a turning point in history where man and homo-reptilia might have lived together in peace, but that time is long past.
ACE: You can’t!
DOCTOR: Do I have to remind you about our recent disagreement with the Galparians? Having saved the world a number of times I’m now, to all intents and purposes, the legal owner of this world...
DOCTOR: . and I have the documentation to prove it.
ACE: Gimme that!
ACE: There’s your documentation!
DOCTOR: I also have a duplicate.
ACE: Not any more!
DOCTOR: It really doesn’t matter, Ace, my claim has been registered in ‘Puterspace, it’s all quite legal and enforceable. This planet is mine to do with as I please.
DOCTOR: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 111
DOCTOR: SCENE 72: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — CAVES
MEL: (TO SELF) How did I get here? I just went through a door, and I’m in some cave system. But this doesn’t look anything like the city. (REALISATION) I must have been on a ship! So is this the island we were headed for?
SPENODUS: (WAY OFF) The human prisoner has escaped, Avvox!
MEL: Uh-oh.
SPENODUS: (WAY OFF) She must be recaptured!
MEL: No, thank-you very much!
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 112
MEL: SCENE 73: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — OFFICE
FALCO: (PRACTICING HIS LINES) “This is an historic moment”. No, come on, get it right, Falco. Gravitas. Gravitas. “This is an historic-
FALCO: Huh?
BLEEPING: BUTTONS, OPENS THE DOOR.
FALCO: Hello?
FALCO: Jodelet?
MEL: (BEHIND WALL) Can anybody hear me?
FALCO: Karla?
MEL: (BEHIND WALL) I’m not Karla, I’m Mel!
FALCO: Mel? (RECOGNISING NAME) Mel! What are you doing behind my wall?
MEL: (BEHIND WALL) I’m in some sort of tunnel! There are some- some “people” after me.
FALCO: Oh, yeah?
MEL: (BEHIND WALL) I think this is some kind of sliding door, but I can’t get it to move!
FALCO: Yeah, there’s a catch built in to the coving. Hang on a minute...
MEL: (BEHIND WALL) Hurry!
MEL: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 113
FALCO: More haste, less speed, my mum used to Say... Got it!
MEL: Oh, thank-you!
FALCO: They tell me this house was built during prohibition, there’s a maze of passages on the island. So you’re the famous Mel, then?
MEL: Famous?
FALCO: I’ve met a lot of people today who’ve been pretty worried about you.
MEL: You’ve seen the Doctor?
FALCO: Yeah, he’s in the presidential library.
MEL: “Presidential”? You’re not- him, are you?
FALCO: Bart Falco, in the flesh, luv. And yeah, I know what you’re thinking.
MEL: I don’t think you do.
FALCO: The answer is yes, it’s real.
MEL: Sorry, what are you talking about? Is there any way we can close this panel?
FALCO: Everybody who meets me wants to know about the hair, that’s OK, it’s not a toupee.
MEL: I really am being followed! Where’s that catch?
FALCO: Give it a tug, if you like. Don’t be scared, I told you, it’s completely real.
FALCO: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 114
SPENODUS: Human! You will answer for what you have done!
MEL: Mr Chairman, we’ve got to run!
FALCO: You’re not gonna pull on it? Just as well, it actually is a toupee. Pretty vain of me, I know.
MEL: Come on!
FALCO: So I’m sorry, you can’t tug on it, ‘cos if you do, it’1ll reveal the micro-filaments.
MEL: Micro...filaments?
FALCO: Yeah, see?
MEL: Oh no. It’s you, you’re the one they’re controlling!
FALCO: Uh-huh. What are your orders, Master?
SPENODUS: She has attacked one of the triad! She must be killed!
SPENODUS: #229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 115

I didn’t mean to hurt Chordok, it was an accident!
There are never any accidents, I always say. As a matter of fact, it was my campaign slogan.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 116
All those who would harm our people must die!
No! Stop, or I’1l1 use this!

Hey!

Whaddya know? I think the power cells have drained.
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 117
SCENE 75: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — LIBRARY
Look, Doctor, I don’t care about your supposed intentions at this particular moment in time, I care about getting out of here, and you seem to be the only one with any ideas.
As well as any real notion of what constitutes a particular moment in time.
He gets like this when he knows he’s wrong. Well, Professor?
Well, what?
How do we get out of here?
Well, it just so happens-
Falco’s Karlas are listening.
(SOTTO) It just so happens that I still have the components I took from the Silurian central chamber. Gather round, please, gather round.
(SOTTO) Sonic screwdriver, Professor?
(SOTTO) No, I’d better do this by hand, I don’t want our guards
getting suspicious.
FX: HE REASSEMBLES THE DEVICE.
(SOTTO) I was planning to reverse its function, but once repaired, it should scramble the Karlas’ circuits.
(SOTTO) Including Karla One’s.
(SOTTO) Oh yes! You better watch where you’re standing, Karla One — you don’t want your microchips fried, do you?
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 118
(AT FULL VOLUME) If it is your wish to fry my microchips, I am incapable of preventing you.
Shhh!
FX: KARLA TWENTY STEPS FORWARD.
I must ask you what you are doing.
THIRTY-NINE:
Please stand and place your hands in the air.
Get behind me, now!
FX: MANTRIC ENERGY BEAM. SPARKS AND CRACKLES IN THE THREE
KARLAS.
My operating functions are severely impaired.
Mine also.
The machine’s burning out! Just a little longer...
THIRTY-NINE:
Karlas Nineteen and Twenty, carry out your instructions to the
best of your-
FX: KARLA THIRTY-NINE EXPLODES. ALL THREE KARLAS COLLAPSE
IN PIECES.
Just in time. Such a pity, they really were wonderful
creations.
Like the human race, if you think about it.
There is little similarity beyond a physical resemblance.
FX: RUTH RUNS THROUGH THE WRECKAGE.
Can we discuss this when we’re out of here?
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 119
FX: SHE TRIES THE DOOR. IT’S LOCKED.
Great. We’re still locked in.
FX: ACE AND THE DOCTOR JOIN RUTH.
It appears to be an electronic lock. Now it’s time for the sonic screwdriver, I think. Should have us out in a jiffy.
FX: SONIC SCREWDRIVER WHIRRS. A CLICK, THE DOOR OPENS.
Just a second, I’1l check. (A BEAT) Coast’s clear, come on.
FX: SHE STEPS OUT.
Hey, Professor, I never noticed that on the sonic screwdriver
before. Is that supposed to be there?
Is what supposed to be where?
Just hand it to me a second.
Here you are.
Thanks, ‘bye!
FX: SHE LEAVES, SLAMMING THE DOOR.
Ace!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 120
SCENE 76: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — OUTSIDE THE LIBRARY (CONT)
FX: THE DOCTOR HAMMERS ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE DOOR
(BEHIND THE DOOR) Ace, let me out!
FX: SONIC SCREWDRIVER WHIRRS.
What are you doing?
FX: DOOR LOCKS.
Locking him in.
FX: THE DOCTOR BANGS ON THE DOOR.
(BEHIND THE DOOR) Don’t do this, Ace!
You know, Professor, I was wrong about why I stick around with you. It’s nothing to do with Pavlov. It’s that after all this time, I just still don’t trust you!
Come on!
(BEHIND THE DOOR) Aaaaaace!
#229: THE SILURIAN CANDIDATE by Matthew J Elliott (FINAL) Page 121
SCENE 77: INT. FALCO’S RETREAT — OFFICE
This gun came off a Karla, yeah? Pretty sweet tech. When I’m done being Chairman, I might just steal this design. Oh wait, I can’t, I’m gonna be dead.
Dead?
Yeah, there’s always something. So want do you want me to do with her, Master? I figure I could choke her, maybe?
It is only right that she should be executed by a member of the triad in the traditional manner.
FX: AVVOX ENTERS.
If you attempt to kill her, Spenodus, we shall all die, and the mission can never be completed.
She attacked Chordok!
Chordok lives!
He does? Oh, thank goodness!
He told me what happened. The human fired her weapon by accident. It would be an ignoble act to kill her.
I agree, ignoble.
Not when she will be soon be dead in any case.
Wait, what?
The balance of mantric energy within the candidate is extremely delicate. A single thermal unit might cause him to explode too soon.
